original_text: Table 1 lists 8 pairs of B decays. In fact, there are more decay pairs, since many of the particles in the final states can be observed as either pseudoscalar (P) or vector (V) mesons. Note that certain decays are written in terms of VV final states, while others are have PP states. There are three reasons for this. First, some decays involve a final-state π0. However, experimentally it will be necessary to find the decay vertices of the final particles. This is virtually impossible for a π0, and so we always use a ρ0. Second, some pairs of decays are related by SU(3) in the SM only if an (ss¯) quark pair is used. However, there are no Ps which are pure (ss¯). The mesons η and η′ have an (ss¯) component, but they also have significant (uu¯) and (dd¯) pieces. As a result the b¯→s¯ and b¯→d¯ decays are not really related by SU(3) in the SM if the final state involves an η or η′. We therefore consider instead the vector meson ϕ which is essentially a pure (ss¯) quark state. Finally, we require that both B0 and B¯0 be able to decay to the final state. This cannot happen if the final state contains a single K0 (or K¯0) meson. However, it can occur if this final-state particle is an excited neutral kaon. In this case one decay involves K*0, while the other has K¯*0. Assuming that the vector meson is detected via its decay to ψKsπ0 (as in the measurement of sin2β via Bd0(t)→J/ψK*), then both B0 and B¯0 can decay to the same final state.
original_translation: La Tabla 1 enumera 8 pares de decaimientos B. De hecho, hay más pares de desintegración, ya que muchas de las partículas en los estados finales pueden ser observadas como mesones pseudoscalares (P) o vectoriales (V). Ten en cuenta que ciertos decaimientos están escritos en términos de estados finales VV, mientras que otros tienen estados PP. Hay tres razones para esto. Primero, algunos decaimientos involucran un π0 en el estado final. Sin embargo, experimentalmente será necesario encontrar los vértices de desintegración de las partículas finales. Esto es virtualmente imposible para un π0, por lo que siempre usamos un ρ0. Segundo, algunos pares de decaimientos están relacionados por SU(3) en el SM solo si se utiliza un par de quarks (ss¯). Sin embargo, no hay Ps que sean puros (ss¯). Los mesones η y η′ tienen un componente (ss¯), pero también tienen piezas significativas (uu¯) y (dd¯). Como resultado, las desintegraciones b¯→s¯ y b¯→d¯ no están realmente relacionadas por SU(3) en el Modelo Estándar si el estado final involucra un η o un η′. Por lo tanto, consideramos en su lugar el mesón vector ϕ que es esencialmente un estado de quark (ss¯) puro. Finalmente, requerimos que tanto B0 como B¯0 puedan decaer al estado final. Esto no puede ocurrir si el estado final contiene un solo mesón K0 (o K¯0). Sin embargo, puede ocurrir si esta partícula en estado final es un kaón neutro excitado. En este caso, una desintegración implica K*0, mientras que la otra tiene K¯*0. Suponiendo que el mesón vector se detecta a través de su decaimiento a ψKsπ0 (como en la medición de sin2β a través de Bd0(t)→J/ψK*), entonces tanto B0 como B¯0 pueden decaer al mismo estado final.

The mesons η and η′ have an (ss¯) component, but they also have significant (uu¯) and (dd¯) pieces.

original_annotated_sentences: Table 1 lists 8 pairs of B decays.
In fact, there are more decay pairs, since many of the particles in the final states can be observed as either pseudoscalar (P) or vector (V) mesons.
Note that certain decays are written in terms of VV final states, while others are have PP states.
There are three reasons for this.
First, some decays involve a final-state π0.
However, experimentally it will be necessary to find the decay vertices of the final particles.
This is virtually impossible for a π0, and so we always use a ρ0.
Second, some pairs of decays are related by SU(3) in the SM only if an (ss¯) quark pair is used.
However, there are no Ps which are pure (ss¯).
The mesons η and η′ have an (ss¯) component, but they also have significant (uu¯) and (dd¯) pieces.
As a result the b¯→s¯ and b¯→d¯ decays are not really related by SU(3) in the SM if the final state involves an η or η′.
We therefore consider instead the vector meson ϕ which is essentially a pure (ss¯) quark state.

Finally, we require that both B0 and B¯0 be able to
decay to the final state
.
This cannot happen if the final state contains a single K0 (or K¯0) meson.
However, it can occur if this final-state particle is an excited neutral kaon.
In this case one decay involves K*0, while the other has K¯*0.
Assuming that the vector meson is detected via its decay to ψKsπ0 (as in the measurement of sin2β via Bd0(t)→J/ψK*), then both B0 and B¯0 can decay to the same final state.

In fact, there are more decay pairs, since many of the particles in the final states can be observed as either pseudoscalar (P) or vector (V) mesons.
Note that certain decays are written in terms of VV final states, while others are have PP states.
There are three reasons for this.
First, some decays involve a final-state π0.
However, experimentally it will be necessary to find the decay vertices of the final particles.
This is virtually impossible for a π0, and so we always use a ρ0.
Second, some pairs of decays are related by SU(3) in the SM only if an (ss¯) quark pair is used.
However, there are no Ps which are pure (ss¯).
The mesons η and η′ have an (ss¯) component, but they also have significant (uu¯) and (dd¯) pieces.
As a result the b¯→s¯ and b¯→d¯ decays are not really related by SU(3) in the SM if the final state involves an η or η′.
We therefore consider instead the vector meson ϕ which is essentially a pure (ss¯) quark state.
Finally, we require that both B0 and B¯0 be able to decay to the final state.
This cannot happen if the final state contains a single K0 (or K¯0) meson.
However, it can occur if this final-state particle is an excited neutral kaon.

In this case one decay involves
K*0
, while the other has K¯*0.
Assuming that the vector meson is detected via its decay to ψKsπ0 (as in the measurement of sin2β via Bd0(t)→J/ψK*), then both B0 and B¯0 can decay to the same final state.

In fact, there are more decay pairs, since many of the particles in the final states can be observed as either pseudoscalar (P) or vector (V) mesons.
Note that certain decays are written in terms of VV final states, while others are have PP states.
There are three reasons for this.
First, some decays involve a final-state π0.
However, experimentally it will be necessary to find the decay vertices of the final particles.
This is virtually impossible for a π0, and so we always use a ρ0.
Second, some pairs of decays are related by SU(3) in the SM only if an (ss¯) quark pair is used.
However, there are no Ps which are pure (ss¯).
The mesons η and η′ have an (ss¯) component, but they also have significant (uu¯) and (dd¯) pieces.
As a result the b¯→s¯ and b¯→d¯ decays are not really related by SU(3) in the SM if the final state involves an η or η′.

We therefore consider instead the vector meson ϕ which is essentially a pure (ss¯)
quark state
.
Finally, we require that both B0 and B¯0 be able to decay to the final state.
This cannot happen if the final state contains a single K0 (or K¯0) meson.
However, it can occur if this final-state particle is an excited neutral kaon.
In this case one decay involves K*0, while the other has K¯*0.
Assuming that the vector meson is detected via its decay to ψKsπ0 (as in the measurement of sin2β via Bd0(t)→J/ψK*), then both B0 and B¯0 can decay to the same final state.
